description.narrative: Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Ethiopia) is a country driven initiative to strengthen and accelerate efforts at national and regional levels across Ethiopia in the development of climate and water information and early warning services. Reliable climate information is crucial to meeting key targets in the growth and transformation plans (GTP), nationally determined contributions, as well as the climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. The National Meteorological Agency, the hydrological services under the Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Electricity and the Ministry of the Environment, Forests and Climate Change are charged with the provision of these information and are the local implementing partners in the WACCA-Ethiopia initiative. The common aim is to develop technical capacity and institutional sustainability for the provision of these key services and this initiative is a direct response to this need. It shall also provide tailored information designed to fit end-under needs with the best available knowledge about the future climate, and develop region specific best-practice solutions for adaptation.

Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Etiopien) är ett landsdrivet initiativ för att stärka och påskynda insatser på nationell och regional nivå i Etiopien i utvecklingen av klimat- och vatteninformation samt tidiga varningssystem. Tillförlitlig klimatinformation är avgörande för att möta nyckelmål i Etiopiens utvecklingsplan s.k. Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP II), klimatåtagade s.k. "nationally determined contributions" under klimatavtalet samt Etiopiens climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. National Meteorological Agency, de hydrologiska tjänsterna under Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Electricity och Ministry of the Environment, Forests and Climate Change är skyldiga att tillhandahålla denna information och är de lokala genomförandepartnerna i WACCA-Etiopien. Det gemensamma målet är att utveckla teknisk kapacitet och institutionell hållbarhet för att tillhandahålla dessa nyckeltjänster och detta projekt är ett direkt svar på detta behov. Projektet ska också tillhandahålla skräddarsydd information som utformats för att passa de slutliga användarna med den bästa tillgängliga kunskapen om det framtida klimatet och utveckla regionspecifika lösningar för bästa praxis för anpassning.

description.narrative: Results achieved is presented in the annual report for 2020, which is for the new programme officer to follow up on. Challenges and major events during 2020 to note for the analysis are: - Programmatic adaptations have been done due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including f ex extending the use of online meeting application. Travels between Sweden and Ethiopia for knowledge and experience exchange have been cancelled due to the pandemic, and budget and workplan have been adjusted accordingly. - No-cost extension made 17 December, as the programme has experienced several delays in implementation of activities both due to COVID-19 as well as issues relating to import of technical equipment. - Sida approved (5th February) of additional funds of 3 MSEK following notification on delegation of funds from Swedish MFA for the final, extended, year of the bilateral strategy. Sida's decision is based on previously sent in budget and workplan for a cost-extension and no-cost extension from SMHI, and following dialogue around the issue. SMHI to send in a formal request and an agreement amendment must be done. Some examples of activities implemented include: -A gender workshop oriented toward male participants at management level was carried out in Addis in February, which is a follow-up of the series of gender workshops carried out during 2019. - Follow-up and continuation of tasks on communication methods and tools from the December study visit to Sweden were carried out. - Planning and preparation for training activities for meteorological forecasting, climatology, hydrological warning operations, hydrological modelling and communication was carried out (but execution was not possible). - Local procurement is underway for ICT training for Ethiopian partners to be conducted by AAIT (Addis Ababa Institute of Technology). This can take place when Government of Ethiopia relaxes its rules on the maximum number of people that can meet. - Coordinating common work activities at MoWIE with the WB hydro-met team. Follow-up and continuation of HYPE modelling training at MoWIE by the local hydrological consultant. - Processing the customs clearance for the first shipment of equipment related to establishing an early warning centre for hydrological forecasting was completed. - The equipment for the hydrological warning centre has successfully been delivered to HWQD at MoWIE. - Technical and safety equipment for use in the field for hydrological monitoring was procured in Sweden and is ready for shipment to Ethiopia, but currently on hold due to high international transport costs resulting from Covid-19. - Procurement of data storage servers for data management at both NMA and HWQD underway, band was on hold due to high international transport costs resulting from COVID-19.
